raw_text:
Labour's 'EU propaganda'
 
 A "taxpayer subsidised propaganda exercise" on the EU is being used to lull the British public into a false sense of security, say the Tories.
 
 Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram told MPs a new White Paper was part of trying to soften up opinion ahead of the referendum on the EU constitution. His claims were denied by Foreign Secretary Jack Straw, who accused the Tories of "running scared" of debate. EU cooperation would help get better UK immigration controls, he argued.
 
 Mr Straw used Thursday's Commons debate to launch the new White Paper on the prospects for the EU in 2005. Security, stability and prosperity would be the key themes when the UK took over the chairmanship of the EU in July, said Mr Straw. Africa and climate change would also feature highly. He said the UK was trying to ensure future EU budgets were limited to 1% of Europe's economic output and were spent "where it adds most value". Mr Straw promised to continue to ensure the UK's budget rebate, secured in 1984 by Margaret Thatcher, was "fully justified". "We, like all other countries, have a veto on any changes proposed in this area," he said.
 
 Mr Ancram condemned the document, which the Foreign Office says has cost about £2,500 to design, print and deliver. "Isn't the reason that the government is now involved in a taxpayer subsidised propaganda exercise to try to sell the new EU to the country in advance of the forthcoming referendum and general election?," he asked. The Tory spokesman also criticised the government for claiming the EU constitution would make Europe easier to understand. "The government, last week, had to publish a commentary of 500 pages to try and explain this 'easy and simple' constitution to the British people," he said. "Who are they trying to kid?" The proposed question for the constitution referendum is: "Should the United Kingdom approve the Treaty establishing a Constitution for the European Union?" The Electoral Commission on Thursday said it was satisfied the question was easy to understand. The government has suggested the referendum on the constitution could take place in spring 2006, with the Tories set to campaign for a "no" vote.
 
 Mr Ancram said ministers were prolonging uncertainty by putting the vote off until the latest date possible. The foreign secretary hit back by saying Tory attitudes to Europe had helped keep the party out of power for more than a decade. Mr Straw argued cooperation with European partners could bring a "level playing field" on immigration and asylum controls. "You are setting your face against all of these things," he added. For the Liberal Democrats, Sir Menzies Campbell said the UK should not ignore the need to reform the EU Common Agricultural Policy. Change was particularly important for developing countries wanting access to markets, he argued. Sir Menzies was among those worried about plans, backed by the UK, to lift the arms embargo imposed on China after the Tiananmen Square massacre. Mr Straw said no decisions had been taken - Chinese human rights had improved but not by enough.
llama3.2:1b: Labour's proposed White Paper on the EU is being criticized for being a "taxpayer subsidised propaganda exercise" and lulling the public into a false sense of security ahead of the referendum on the EU constitution.
Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram accused the government of trying to soften up opinion with a new document that costs £2,500 to design, print, and deliver.
The Foreign Secretary Jack Straw defended the document as part of an effort to ensure European stability and prosperity during the UK's chairmanship in 2005.
Ancram criticized the document for claiming the EU constitution would make Europe easier to understand, while the Electoral Commission found it easy to understand.
The government has suggested the EU constitution referendum could take place in spring 2006, with the Tories set to campaign for a "no" vote.
llama3.2:3b: Tories claim EU document is a "taxpayer subsidised propaganda exercise" to soften public opinion ahead of referendum and general election.
Foreign Secretary Jack Straw denies this, saying cooperation with European partners could bring better UK immigration controls.
Straw promises to limit future EU budgets to 1% of Europe's economic output.
The proposed EU constitution referendum question has been deemed easy to understand by the Electoral Commission.
gemma2:2b: The Tory party accuses the government of using a new White Paper on EU prospects as "taxpayer subsidized propaganda" to influence public opinion before the EU constitution referendum.
The Foreign Secretary claims this is part of ensuring the UK takes over EU chairmanship in July with its focus on security, stability and prosperity.
He also defends limiting EU budgets to 1% of Europe's economic output and promises to continue the UK's budget rebate.
Critics argue the government's efforts are misguided and that EU reforms are needed, especially regarding agricultural policy and China's human rights record.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Tories are lulling public into believing the EU will benefit Britain in advance of a referendum.
They accuse the Tories of "running scared" before the vote, suggesting they want to soften up opinions and avoid conflict with Brussels.

Shadow Foreign Secretary Michael Ancram claims the new White Paper will help secure better UK immigration controls and aid in limiting EU budget spending and European Union (EU) member-state relationships.

He also says the government is running a taxpayer subsidised propaganda exercise to sell the EU to the British public before the upcoming referendum, while criticising the foreign secretary's claim that the EU constitution would make Europe simpler.

Foreign Secretary Jack Straw argues for a more cautious approach with his new White Paper, promising to protect UK budget rebates from 1% economic output and adhere strictly to "where it adds most value".
He claims the UK wants to ensure future EU budgets are limited to just 1% of Europe's economy.
However, he suggests this could be achieved through a European Union Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) reform.
Liberal Democrat Shadow Home Secretary Nick Grieve argues for stronger EU institutions and reforms in the European Union.
For British politicians, these issues often make them wary of the EU, especially when Brexit discussions are on the cards.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The Tories claim EU propaganda exercise is misleading British public ahead of referendum and general election.
Shadow Foreign Secretary criticizes new White Paper, which costs £2,500 to design, print and deliver.
UK's stance on the EU constitution questioned as government claims it would make Europe easier to understand despite complex nature of the text.
The proposed constitution question for referendum is "Should the United Kingdom approve the Treaty establishing a Constitution for the European Union?
qwen2.5:3b: Labour criticises the government for a taxpayer-funded propaganda campaign promoting the EU constitution ahead of referendum and general election.

Shadow foreign secretary Michael Ancram claims it is an attempt to deceive the public, while Foreign Secretary Jack Straw defends the initiative as beneficial for UK interests in areas like immigration control and budget management.
Ancram also argues that explaining the EU constitution requires extensive documentation.
The proposed referendum question asks if the UK should approve the EU Constitution.
Tory MPs emphasize the need for improved UK-EU cooperation on issues such as asylum, while Lib Dems advocate reform of the Common Agricultural Policy.
Sir Menzies Campbell warns against lifting China's arms embargo due to human rights concerns.

The Foreign Secretary's claims that the UK would be running scared if it didn't accept the EU constitution are denied by the Foreign Office, which argues that the UK has a veto over any changes proposed in this area.

The Labour's "EU propaganda" idea suggests that the Tories' campaign to promote the EU as a positive force for Britain is not genuine and may be used to distract from their own negative policies on Europe.

Straw also criticized the government for claiming the EU constitution simplifies Europe too much without context, while supporting claims that China's arms embargo on Taiwan may affect human rights.

The vote is set to end in spring 2006, intended to prevent the Tories from being re-elected for more than a decade.

Ministers have been prolonging political uncertainty by putting the vote off until the latest date possible but the Liberal Democrats argued that reform was important for developing countries looking to access European markets.

The Tories' new White Paper suggests a shift towards a more open and inclusive approach to the EU by emphasizing the importance of cooperation with partners such as Africa and climate change, while also advocating for a less restrictive immigration policy.

The Liberal Democrats, led by Sir Menzies Campbell, have expressed concerns over the proposed reform of the EU Common Agricultural Policy, which could potentially benefit developing countries seeking access to markets.
The EU arms embargo imposed on China after the Tiananmen Square massacre also comes under debate, with no decisions made as of yet.

The proposed question for the constitution referendum is: "Should the United Kingdom approve the Treaty establishing a Constitution for the European Union?"
The Electoral Commission on Thursday said it was satisfied with the question.

Straw outlined the UK's EU priorities, including security, stability, and budget constraints, while reaffirming the UK's budget rebate.
Ancram dismissed claims that the EU constitution would simplify governance, pointing to a lengthy government commentary explaining it.
The referendum, expected in spring 2006, would see the Tories campaigning for a "no" vote.
